summary: This is a letter from defense attorney Jeffrey S. Pagliuca to the U.S. Attorney's Office, outlining Ghislaine Maxwell's good faith objections to certain categories of alleged co-conspirator hearsay statements the government intends to use at trial. The objections focus on temporal limitations, the scope of 'minor victims,' and whether statements were made during or in furtherance of the alleged conspiracy.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell, whose defense counsel is objecting to the admission of certain hearsay statements.

persons.name: Jeffrey S. Pagliuca
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell, authoring this letter to the U.S. Attorney's Office outlining objections to proffered hearsay evidence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Referred to as a co-conspirator; the letter objects to statements he allegedly made to employees, friends, and family of minor victims, arguing some post-date the conspiracy.

persons.name: CC-1
persons.context: An individual (co-conspirator 1) who allegedly received statements from Epstein and CC-2; referenced in examples of objected-to hearsay.

persons.name: CC-2
persons.context: An individual (co-conspirator 2) who allegedly made statements to friends and family of minor victims and gave direction to CC-1.

connections.description: Pagliuca is defense counsel for Maxwell, as evidenced by him writing this objection letter on her behalf.
Implied by the context of the case and the objection to statements about Maxwell allegedly made by Epstein to others.
The letter references alleged statements from Epstein to his employee, CC-1.
Both are referred to as co-conspirators giving direction or making statements related to the alleged conspiracy.
The letter cites an example where CC-2 and Epstein gave direction to CC-1.

events.title: Court Order on Hearsay Statements
events.description: The Court issued an order, presumably related to the proffering of co-conspirator hearsay statements in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Government Correspondence on Minor Victims
events.description: The government sent correspondence to defense counsel identifying specific 'minor victims' relevant to the case.

locations: United States Attorney's Office Southern District of New York, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
Haddon, Morgan and Foreman, P.C., 150 East 16th Avenue, Denver, CO
keyFacts: The defense for Ghislaine Maxwell is formally objecting to several categories of alleged co-conspirator hearsay statements the government plans to use at trial.

A key objection is that some statements, like Epstein allegedly telling CC-1 that Maxwell 'used to find girls for him,' may post-date the alleged conspiracy and constitute 'idle chatter' not made in furtherance of it.

The defense seeks to limit the scope of 'minor victims' to only those specifically identified by the government in its October 11, 2021, correspondence, excluding other alleged victims from prior Florida investigations.
The defense objects to hearsay statements lacking temporal limitations, arguing they should be confined to the dates of the alleged conspiracy.

The document references direction from Epstein and CC-2 to CC-1 to 'help someone who was coming to take the computers,' which the defense argues does not appear to be during or in furtherance of the charged conspiracy.
